content.statement: aku-002-fundamental-theorem-arithmetic is a fundamental concept in Science Math Number-Theory Primes that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding aku-002-fundamental-theorem-arithmetic helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of aku-002-fundamental-theorem-arithmetic include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of aku-002-fundamental-theorem-arithmetic.

definitions_glossary.prime_factorization: The representation of a number as a product of prime powers
definitions_glossary.canonical_form: The standard representation p₁^e₁ · p₂^e₂ · ... · pₖ^eₖ with primes in ascending order
definitions_glossary.multiplicity: The exponent eᵢ indicating how many times prime pᵢ appears in the factorization
definitions_glossary.euclids_lemma: If prime p divides ab, then p divides a or p divides b
definitions_glossary.strong_induction: Proof technique assuming statement holds for all smaller values

applications: Computing GCD and LCM using prime factorizations
Cryptography - RSA relies on difficulty of factoring large composites
Algebraic number theory - generalizations and counterexamples

existence: Base case: n = 2 is prime, factorization is just 2
Induction: If n is prime, done. If composite, n = ab with 1 < a, b < n
By induction hypothesis, a and b have prime factorizations
Combine factorizations to get factorization of n
uniqueness: Assume n has two factorizations: p₁...pᵣ = q₁...qₛ
By Euclid's Lemma, p₁ divides some qⱼ
Since qⱼ is prime, p₁ = qⱼ

definition.@value: Every integer greater than 1 is either prime or can be uniquely represented as a product of prime numbers

prerequisites.title: Prime Numbers
prerequisites.reason: Must understand prime numbers to understand their unique factorization property

enables.title: GCD and LCM Computation
enables.reason: Prime factorizations enable efficient GCD/LCM algorithms

enables.title: RSA Factoring Problem
enables.reason: RSA security depends on difficulty of factoring into primes

enables.title: Divisor Functions
enables.reason: Computing number of divisors uses prime factorization

related.relationship: Some number systems lack unique factorization (e.g., ℤ[√-5])
Finding prime factorization is computationally hard for large numbers
Breaking RSA requires efficient factorization algorithms

skos:related.skos:note: Algebraic generalization to other number systems

learning_objectives: State the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic accurately
Understand both existence and uniqueness parts
Compute prime factorizations for concrete numbers
Appreciate the significance for number theory and applications
Recognize where unique factorization fails (other number systems)
common_errors: Forgetting that uniqueness is 'up to order' of factors
Not distinguishing between existence and uniqueness
Thinking the theorem is obvious (uniqueness requires proof)
Not understanding why this makes integers special
teaching_tips: Emphasize 'up to order' with examples like 12 = 2×2×3 = 3×2×2
Connect to chemistry analogy: primes as atoms, composites as molecules
Discuss applications in cryptography to show real-world importance
